title: 113_hr2334
content: The "STEM Support for Teachers in Education and Mentoring (STEM) Act" or the "STEM Act" amends Title II of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to include a new section focused on STEM education planning and training. The Act defines STEM as science, technology, engineering, and mathematics, and provides for planning grants in this area. The section aims to address the lack of coordination in STEM education efforts among States by providing grants to eligible entities to develop effective State or tribal STEM networks for communication and collaboration. Eligible entities include States, Indian tribes, tribal organizations, nonprofits, or higher education institutions that form coalitions to participate in grant applications and subsequent STEM network activities. The section focuses on providing grants to eligible entities to establish State or tribal STEM networks for communication and collaboration. The grants aim to identify future STEM skills needed for various occupations, with a focus on high-need and high-poverty entities. Eligible entities must submit an application containing required information to the Secretary. Reports on the progress of the grants are also required. The STEM Support for Teachers in Education and Mentoring (STEM) Act requires eligible entities receiving grants to submit annual progress reports to the Secretary. Additionally, the Secretary must submit a report to Congress every 3 years regarding the program supported under this section. Additionally, the Secretary must submit a report to Congress every 3 years regarding the program supported under this section. SEC. 2503. TRAINING PROGRAM GRANTS. The section aims to enhance teachers' capacity in STEM education through grants awarded to eligible entities for developing and implementing training programs in elementary, middle, and secondary schools. Eligible entities include states, tribes, educational agencies, higher education institutions, and nonprofit organizations. The section focuses on providing grants to eligible entities for STEM education training programs in schools, ensuring equitable distribution between urban and rural areas, and high-need entities. Eligible entities must submit an application to the Secretary for grant consideration. The eligible entity receiving a grant must monitor and evaluate the training program's effectiveness, measure its impact on teachers, and use funds for professional development in STEM education for existing and preservice teachers. The eligible entity receiving a grant must submit annual progress reports to the Secretary and the results of the evaluation. The Secretary will also submit a report to Congress every three years regarding the program supported under this section. "SEC. 2504. ACADEMIC STANDARDS GRANTS." The purpose of this section is to strengthen States' capacity to implement new mathematics and science academic standards by awarding grants to eligible entities for curriculum development and related activities. Eligible entities include States, Indian tribes, local educational agencies, public charter schools, institutions of higher education, and nonprofit organizations. Grants will be awarded on a competitive basis to support the adoption of new standards. The Secretary will prioritize grant funds for high-need and high-poverty eligible entities. Eligible entities must submit an application detailing how they will monitor curriculum effectiveness and use funds for curriculum development. The section utilizes grant funds for curriculum development, assessments, and professional development on STEM education standards for teachers and administrators. Eligible entities must submit annual progress reports to the Secretary. "SEC. 2505. NATIONAL PANEL." The Secretary will establish a national panel to review and identify effective STEM curricula models and best practices. Panel members will include representatives from technology industries, teachers, school administrators, nonprofit organizations, and faculty from higher education institutions. The national panel established by the Secretary will include faculty members, research specialists, a rural education expert, a student for youth perspective, and other individuals as deemed appropriate. The panel will prepare reports and recommendations on their findings as requested by the Secretary. Authorization of appropriations for STEM Education Planning and Training is provided for fiscal year 2014 and the following 5 years.
